Class Vector3D

java.lang.Object
us.stomberg.solarsystemsim.physics.Vector3D
public class Vector3D extends Object
The Vector3D class represents a three-dimensional vector with x, y, and z components.

This immutable data structure serves as a fundamental building block for:

  • Representing positions in 3D space
  • Storing velocities and accelerations of bodies
  • Calculating gravitational forces and trajectories
  • Performing vector mathematics (addition, scaling, normalization, etc.)

The class provides both immutable operations (which return new Vector3D instances) and mutable operations (with "InPlace" suffix, which modify the current instance). The mutable operations support method chaining for composing complex vector operations efficiently.

Vector3D implements essential vector mathematics including addition, subtraction, scaling, normalization, dot product, and various utility methods for physics simulations.

    • copyFrom

      public Vector3D copyFrom(Vector3D vector)
      Sets all components of this vector to match those of another vector.

      This is a mutable operation that modifies the current vector instance. It provides an efficient way to update a vector's values without creating a new object.

      Parameters:
      vector - The source vector whose components will be copied
      Returns:
      This vector instance, allowing for method chaining
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the input vector is null

    • add

      public Vector3D add(Vector3D vector)
      Sums two vectors. Adds the corresponding components separately. This method returns a new vector rather than setting the values of this vector.
      Parameters:
      vector - The second vector.
      Returns:
      The sum of both vectors.

    • addInPlace

      public Vector3D addInPlace(Vector3D vector)
      Adds another vector to this vector, modifying this vector in place.

      This method performs elementwise addition of the components of the two vectors. It modifies the current vector instance rather than creating a new one, making it more efficient for cumulative operations.

      Parameters:
      vector - The vector to add to this vector
      Returns:
      This vector instance, allowing for method chaining
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the input vector is null

    • scale

      public Vector3D scale(double factor)
      Multiplies a vector with another number. This value multiplies each component. This function is used to scale a vector.
      Parameters:
      factor - The factor by which to scale the vector.
      Returns:
      The scaled vector.

    • scaleInPlace

      public Vector3D scaleInPlace(double factor)
      Multiplies a vector with another number. This value multiplies each component. This function is used to scale a vector.
      Parameters:
      factor - The factor by which to scale the vector.
      Returns:
      The scaled vector.

    • addAndScaleInPlace

      public Vector3D addAndScaleInPlace(Vector3D vector, double factor)
      Adds a scaled version of another vector to this vector.

      This method performs the operation: this += vector * factor

      This combined operation is particularly useful in numerical integration algorithms where a scaled vector needs to be added to an accumulator. It is more efficient than separate scale and add operations as it requires only one pass through the vector components.

      Parameters:
      vector - The vector to be scaled and added
      factor - The scaling factor to apply to the vector
      Returns:
      This vector instance, allowing for method chaining
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the input vector is null

    • setToZero

      public Vector3D setToZero()
      Sets all components of this vector to zero.

      This method resets the vector to the origin point (0,0,0) in 3D space. It is more efficient than creating a new zero vector or setting each component individually.

      Returns:
      This vector instance, allowing for method chaining

    • negate

      public Vector3D negate()
      Creates a new vector with all components negated.

      This method returns a new vector pointing in the opposite direction with the same magnitude as the original vector.

      Returns:
      A new vector with all components negated

    • negateInPlace

      public Vector3D negateInPlace()
      Negates all components of this vector in place.

      This method reverses the direction of the vector while maintaining its magnitude. It modifies the current vector instance rather than creating a new one.

      Returns:
      This vector instance, allowing for method chaining

    • subtract

      public Vector3D subtract(Vector3D vector)
      Gets the differences between the corresponding components of two vectors. Subtracts the second vector from the first vector. Returned as an array of values.
      Parameters:
      vector - The second vector.
      Returns:
      Returns the x, y, and z difference.

    • subtractInPlace

      public Vector3D subtractInPlace(Vector3D vector)
      Gets the differences between the corresponding components of two vectors. Subtracts the second vector from the first vector. Returned as an array of values.
      Parameters:
      vector - The second vector.
      Returns:
      Returns the x, y, and z difference.

    • distance

      public double distance(Vector3D vector)
      Calculates the Euclidean distance between this vector and another vector in 3D space.

      This method computes the straight-line distance between two points represented by the vectors, using the Pythagorean formula:

      distance = √((x₂-x₁)² + (y₂-y₁)² + (z₂-z₁)²)

      This is a fundamental operation in physics simulations for determining the separation between bodies.

      Parameters:
      vector - The second vector to calculate distance to
      Returns:
      The Euclidean distance between the two vectors
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the input vector is null

    • magnitude

      public double magnitude()
      Returns the vector's 3D distance to (0, 0, 0). Is equal to the vector's magnitude.
      Returns:
      Returns the vector's magnitude.

    • angleTo

      public Vector3D angleTo(Vector3D vector)
      Calculates a normalized direction vector pointing from this vector to another.

      This method creates a unit vector (magnitude of 1) in the direction from this vector to the specified target vector. It is computed as:

      (target - this).normalize()

      This is useful for determining the direction of gravitational forces, movement trajectories, or any calculation requiring only directional information.

      Parameters:
      vector - The target vector to find direction toward
      Returns:
      A normalized vector pointing from this vector to the target
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the input vector is null

    • normalize

      public Vector3D normalize()
      Gets a vector representing only the vector's direction, its angle to (0, 0, 0).
      Returns:
      Returns a vector on a unit scale to represent angle.

    • normalizeInPlace

      public Vector3D normalizeInPlace()
      Gets a vector representing only the vector's direction, its angle to (0, 0, 0).
      Returns:
      Returns a vector on a unit scale to represent angle.

    • interpolate

      public Vector3D interpolate(Vector3D other, double p)
      Creates a new vector by linearly interpolating between this vector and another.

      The interpolation parameter p controls the blend:

      • When p = 0, the result equals this vector
      • When p = 1, the result equals the other vector
      • When 0 < p < 1, the result is a proportional blend

      This method can be used to smoothly transition between two positions, velocities, or other vector quantities.

      Parameters:
      other - The target vector to interpolate toward
      p - The interpolation parameter (typically between 0 and 1)
      Returns:
      A new vector representing the interpolated result
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the other vector is null

    • interpolateInPlace

      public Vector3D interpolateInPlace(Vector3D other, double p)
      Linearly interpolates this vector toward another vector in place.

      This method modifies the current vector instance by moving it partially toward the target vector according to parameter p:

      • When p = 0, this vector remains unchanged
      • When p = 1, this vector becomes equal to the other vector
      • When 0 < p < 1, this vector moves proportionally toward the other

      This operation is commonly used in collision physics to calculate the new position of a merged body based on the mass-weighted average of the colliding bodies.

      Parameters:
      other - The target vector to interpolate toward
      p - The interpolation parameter (typically between 0 and 1)
      Returns:
      This vector instance, allowing for method chaining
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the other vector is null

    • dotProduct

      public double dotProduct(Vector3D vector)
      Calculates the dot product between this vector and another vector.
      Parameters:
      vector - The other vector to calculate dot product with
      Returns:
      the scalar dot product of the two vectors

    • copy

      public Vector3D copy()
      Create a new Vector3D with identical values.
      Returns:
      Returns the copied vector.

    • toString

      public String toString(String unit)
      Formats the vector into a string representation with specified units.

      This method generates a human-readable string representation of the vector with properly formatted values and unit labels. For large values, it will automatically convert to appropriate unit scales (e.g., kilometers).

      Example output: "Vector3D(x=149.6 Mkm, y=0.00 km, z=0.00 km)"

      Parameters:
      unit - The base unit to display (e.g., "m", "km")
      Returns:
      A formatted string with components and appropriate units

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Formats the vector into a string representation without units.

      This method generates a human-readable string representation of the vector with properly formatted values.

      Example output: "Vector3D(x=149.60, y=0.00, z=0.00)"

      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Returns:
      Returns a string expressing the vector.
